newsitem.title: UK: London gold prices turn easier in very quiet trade.
newsitem.headline: London gold prices turn easier in very quiet trade.

text.p: Precious metals were stuck in a narrow and lower range on Thursday compared with prices earlier this week in a market which dealers described as gloomy.
Gold was fixed at $388.05 per ounce after $388.50 on Wednesday and a close of $388.55.
"Physical business is beginning to kick in but it is doing no more than mopping up any surplus," a dealer said, adding that he did not get bullish for gold until late September.
"I don't expect to see much before that and meanwhile the physical offtake is taking up any profit-taking from the longs (holders of gold) who bought in the rally from $381 to $389," he added.
Both New York and the Far East were quiet and featureless overnight with gold marginally easier in New York and regaining European closing levels in Tokyo.
Dealers said the precious metals would probably remain quiet this week ahead of the three-day U.S. Labor Day weekend.
Silver was no more exiting but dealers' and analysts' views varied on the medium-term price trend.
"Silver has been mixed and very difficult to figure out. Until gold starts to move I can see it sitting in a $5.15-$5.25 range," one dealer said.
Others were less optimistic, seeing silver losing ground after its continual failure to get over $5.25 per ounce earlier this week.
Platinum and palladium were also lukewarm with platinum indicated down $0.25 at $399.75 and palladium 80 cents easier at $126.20.
